instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00840: What is 820-00840? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.PP5V_S5: What is PP5V_S5? This is a 5v power rail that is present when the machine is in an S5 soft off state..
definitions.PP3V3_G3H: What is PP3V3_G3H? PP3V3_G3H is a 3.3v power line that is present when the machine is in a Global System Hardware Off state, and should come on before most other rails so that the USB-C circuitry can be powered for the charger.
definitions.PPDCIN_G3H: What is PPDCIN_G3H? PPDCIN_G3H Is a power rail that comes directly from the laptop charger..
definitions.SMC_PM_G2_EN: What is SMC_PM_G2_EN? SMC_PM_G2_EN is a signal that comes from the SMC that is a prerequsite for all of the enable signals for the S5 rails to come on, such as P3V3S5_EN. S5 rails will not come on if SMC_PM_G2_EN is not coming..
definitions.PP3V3_SUS: What is PP3V3_SUS? The "PP3V3_SUS" rail on a MacBook logic board is a power rail that provides a 3.3-volt supply to the suspend-to-RAM (S3 state) components. .
definitions.PP1V8_S3: What is PP1V8_S3? The PP1V8_S3 signal in the MacBook schematic is a power rail that provides a voltage of 1.8 volts during the S3 power state. The S3 state, often referred to as "suspend to RAM," is a low-power mode where the computer saves the session's state to RAM, allowing for quicker wake-up times compared to a full shutdown..
definitions.U7000: What is U7000? U7000 refers to the ISL6258 or ISL6259 charging IC on Macbooks from 2008-2012.
definitions.3V3_S5: What is 3V3_S5? 3V3_S5 and PP3V3_S5 are interchangeable, see definition for PP3V3_S5. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> dead.
threads.message:
the board was work on an off sometime was turn on and sometime not.
Board without battery, unplugged all connectors takes from charger:
20.33V
0.052A

Power rails:
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> - 13.7V
<SIGNAL>PPDCIN_G3H</SIGNAL> - 20.35V
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL> - 0V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> - 3.426V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> - 0V
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_S3</SIGNAL> - 0V 
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_SUS</SIGNAL> - 0.00v
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> - 0.00v 
<SIGNAL>BUF_SMC_RESET_L</SIGNAL> - 3.424v
<SIGNAL>SMC_PM_G2_EN</SIGNAL> - 3.420v 

<CHIP>U7890</CHIP>:

1 <SIGNAL>SSD_PWR_REQ</SIGNAL> - 0v
2 <SIGNAL>PMIC_EN_P3V3S5</SIGNAL> - 0v
4 <SIGNAL>PM_EN_PVXS5</SIGNAL> - 0v
6 <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> - 3,42v 

<CHIP>U7800</CHIP> was burnd when i was do checking this rails but i was replaced and now i get this voltage
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_PMIC</SIGNAL> -13v
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_LDO3V</SIGNAL> - 3.3v
<SIGNAL>PMIC_SHUTDOWN_L</SIGNAL> 3.2v

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> dead.
threads.message:
<CHIP>U7800</CHIP> was burnt, or got burnt when you made some short measuring on the board?

<SIGNAL>1V25_VREF</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>3V1_RTC</SIGNAL> present?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> dead.
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> dead.
threads.message:
Check for moved components, reflow <CHIP>U7800</CHIP>; be sure to get good solders.
The heat could affected other chips, is other option.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> dead.
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> dead.
threads.message: Maybe CPU, or SMC; the heat could affected them...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> dead.
threads.message: i was just sew a little bit corrosion under <TRANSISTOR>Q3100</TRANSISTOR> clean and replaced but the same...charger without battery  20V 0.23A can it be the from there?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> dead.
threads.message:
If you don't even get <SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL>, 0.23A is too high.
20V means the USB-C area is good.

You may have a problem around <CHIP>U7000</CHIP>/800.
